In his first public comment on the May 19 suspension of the priest, the Rev. Luis Barrios of St. Ann's Church, in Mott Haven, Bishop Richard F. Grein said that the outcry over the priest's suspension was fueled by nonparishioners who exacerbated tensions, which culminated in a disruption of services last Sunday and a death threat against the priest who celebrated the Mass.

nytimes_articles.headline: Black-Majority Districts: A Bad Idea
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The collapse of Lani Guinier's nomination as chief of the Justice Department's civil rights division stemmed, not surprisingly, from her distrust of the democratic process and her failure to acknowledge African-Americans' significant progress under the Voting Rights Act. She favors artificial schemes for increasing the political power of ethnic minorities.

I disagree. African-Americans, for example, cannot benefit from the continued emphasis on segregating black voters in black-majority districts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Patrol of Park Is Intensified After Slaying
nytimes_articles.abstract: Police officers in helicopters, patrol cars and on scooters, horses and bicycles circled Prospect Park yesterday, an almost-military presence amid the park's jewel-like lakes and meadows, as detectives investigated the killing of a 42-year-old drama teacher shot four times in the back as he bicycled along a secluded path.   There were few leads by evening in the slaying of Allyn Winslow, who somehow managed to pedal his bicycle nearly 400 yards before he collapsed and died Tuesday afternoon in a bed of clover.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Albany, Dinkins's Fiscal Gantlet; Mayor Faces Stumbling Blocks From Allies and the G.O.P.
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the delicate dance that every New York City mayor performs when seeking state aid, Mayor David N. Dinkins has rarely been mistaken for Fred Astaire.   He has been criticized for not comprehending the Kremlinesque intrigue of Statehouse politics, for not lobbying state legislators enough, for crying wolf.   But this is a year Mr. Dinkins seems destined to stumble despite his best efforts, as he seeks $280 million in state aid to help close a $500 million budget gap. His allies seem weaker, his opponents more determined and the independents more complacent than usual. Trouble Across the Divide    For Democrats, the problem is largely the state's tight budget. Behind public talk about supporting Mr. Dinkins, there is much private hand wringing about a sluggish economy that has left them few resources for a bailout and many excuses for whittling down the city's plan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Council Panel Weighs Case Against Ruiz
nytimes_articles.abstract: A City Council committee met privately yesterday to consider charges that Councilman Israel Ruiz Jr. registered and voted in 1991 using a fake address, moments after Mr. Ruiz offered an impassioned denial on the Council floor.   The meeting by the Committee on Standards and Ethics -- the second time in a week in which it has taken up allegations that members have provided false information about their residences -- followed an impassioned denial of the charge by Mr. Ruiz before the full Council. Mr. Ruiz, a Bronx Democrat, said he had been falsely accused in newspaper articles, and he demanded a public hearing into the charges.

nytimes_articles.headline: Labor Dispute May Disrupt A Tournament
nytimes_articles.abstract: Less than a week before the Westchester Country Club welcomes some of the world's greatest golfers under the glare of a national television audience, a group of 65 striking kitchen and dining-room employees is threatening to disrupt the tournament unless its nine-month-old dispute with the club can be settled.   The dispute -- in which the two sides have disagreed over wage increases, overtime scheduling, and health and pension benefits -- was heightened this morning when Westchester County authorities evicted 17 striking workers from the dormitory rooms that the club had provided them as part of their jobs. The workers had received the court-ordered eviction notices last week and most had already moved in with friends or other strikers by the time the authorities arrived.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemala's Counter-Coup: A Military About-Face
nytimes_articles.abstract: When President Jorge Serrano Elias startled Guatemalans last week with the announcement that he was dissolving the Congress and suspending the Constitution, his seizure of power seemed to have been accomplished at a stroke. The military, which had led many coups in the past, backed his actions and not a protester appeared in public.   But on Monday, the military switched sides and ousted Mr. Serrano. Today he flew to El Salvador, and the State Department in Washington said he was expected to travel to Texas to visit his ailing mother.

nytimes_articles.headline: Balanced Trade for All : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Every nation should be entitled to a balanced trade account within international trade rules and without regard to underlying causes. For instance any nation with a trade deficit that exceeds 5 percent of exports would be entitled to impose tariffs on th

nytimes_articles.headline: G.E. Gives Midtown Tower To Columbia University
nytimes_articles.abstract: A century after moving its campus from mid-Manhattan, Columbia University returned yesterday to accept the 50-story General Electric Building at 570 Lexington Avenue as a gift from the General Electric Company.   The slender landmark Art Deco skyscraper at 51st Street -- ornamented by lightning bolts and electric rays -- is valued at $40 million.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pacers Are Talking to Brown
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sixteen years ago, LARRY BROWN talked DONNIE WALSH back into coaching. Now the roles are reversed. It's Walsh who's doing the talking, and the Indiana Pacers' president hopes his old friend will respond to his sales pitch.   Walsh, whose first National Basketball Association coaching job was as Brown's assistant in Denver, was in Los Angeles yesterday to meet with Brown and the team's owner, HERB SIMON.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; Crown Heights Was Not Iasi
nytimes_articles.abstract: As someone who grew up hearing her father's recollections of violent anti-Semitism in Poland, may I suggest that New York City politicians give the word "pogrom" a rest. It's legitimate to argue that the police did a bad job of protecting the Jewish population in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section during the riots in the summer of 1991. The police did do a bad job. But to call the riots a pogrom, as former Mayor Edward Koch, the mayoral candidate Rudolph Giuliani and others persist in doing, is not only wrong -- and inflammatory -- but an insult to those who lived through the real thing.    My late father didn't speak often about his childhood in Eastern Europe. But when he did it was with a steely anger, a transforming bitterness that he carried with him all 89 years of his life. Though he left Poland when he was only 6, he could vividly recall nights when Cossacks would sweep through his village on horseback, beating, maiming and murdering Jews for one reason -- because they were Jewish. He remembered fleeing and hiding, and he remembered the confused fear of a child who could not make sense of what was, after all, incomprehensible.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Two-Faced West : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "One Face of Islam" (Letters, May 18) by Robert J. Wolfson: .It is time the West stopped trumpeting its "sensitivity" to the virtues of democracy, liberty, human rights and such. .The rest of the world, although it fails

nytimes_articles.headline: Witches and Homosexuals : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is disheartening to read the absurdities of those who want discrimination against homosexuals to continue. Yet some people claim that a separate morality must govern homosexuals - which is a laugh, coming from that macho tribe that treats women like d

nytimes_articles.headline: Smith Goes Up, but Only Knicks Drop
nytimes_articles.abstract: The play seemed to last forever, a lifetime of opportunity for Charles Smith to win the night for the Knicks. Under the basket with the ball, his team down a point and the fourth-quarter seconds ticking away, Smith went up, up, up and up. Every time, he came down with the ball. Every time, it felt like a bell tolling for the Knicks.   The score was 95-94, the Bulls hanging on, the Knicks with the ball and 28.8 seconds left in what could very well be the last game of the season in New York. Patrick Ewing had started a drive against Stacey King, lost his footing, and shoveled the ball to Smith to the left of the basket.

nytimes_articles.headline: Innocence Abroad : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "U.S. Trade Gap Soars as Imports Reach a Record" (Business/Finance, May 20) by Keith Bradsher: .Through a naive tax system, which makes other countries laugh, the United States guarantees that overseas Americans will always be at a

nytimes_articles.headline: What Price Patriotism?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
How much would you pay for the privilege of serving your country? If President Clinton's proposed national service plan gets off the ground, a lot of young people will ask themselves that question. Evidently the designers of the plan must hope the appetite for sacrifice is strong.

Here's the deal. To get $5,000 in school loans forgiven, graduates will have to work for a year in national service, with a guaranteed minimum-wage stipend of a little under $9,000, typically in schools, parks, the auxilary police and similar jobs.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Marshall Papers Case, Library Abuses Trust
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   All who knew Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall well have no doubt that the Library of Congress has seriously and grievously abused the discretion that he bestowed on it by releasing his private papers so soon after his retirement from the Supreme Court and his death (front page, May 25). His passionate wish to preserve the confidentiality of the Court conference room and his colleagues' debates was clear to all of us who were close to him.   James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress, did not know Justice Marshall. Thus, he may honestly believe he is acting in accordance with Justice Marshall's wishes. But he is wrong. And his assertion that confessing error will hurt the library suggests that even Mr. Billington may now have some doubts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hrudey Can't Fail Between the Pipes for Kings
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the middle of the season, Kelly Hrudey's job was in jeopardy and he felt as secure as a loose rebound in the goal crease. He worried that he would become a backup goalie. He feared that he was about to be traded by the Los Angeles Kings, even though "I was probably playing so poorly that nobody wanted me."   Now, Hrudey is the first-string goalie again and his team has a 1-0 lead over the Montreal Canadiens in the Stanley Cup finals. The four-of-seven-game championship series resumes here Thursday night. Hrudey stopped 31 shots in Game 1, a 4-1 Los Angeles victory Tuesday night. For one game, at least, Hrudey was better than Montreal's Patrick Roy. An Inner Anger    Hrudey says he has never had so much fun in his life, but he says it without a smile and in a way that suggests an inner anger. When he said today that "I don't want hockey to distract me from what's important in life," someone asked him what is important in his life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Texas Court Stays Execution for Slaying in 1981
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals granted a stay of execution today to Gary Graham, who had been scheduled to die by lethal injection after midnight for the 1981 murder of a 53-year-old Arizona businessman, Bobby Lambert, in a supermarket parking lot here.   The court unanimously voted to stay Mr. Graham's execution, pending a decision by the United States Supreme Court in another case, probably later this month. But the court sidestepped what many considered the crucial issue in Mr. Graham's case: the lack of a judicial forum to hear new evidence of his assertion that he is not guilty. In a 5-to-4 decision, the court declined to consider the issue of new evidence.

nytimes_articles.headline: Majority on Board Seeks New Chancellor Quickly
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Board of Education wrangled over the pace of its search for a new schools chancellor yesterday, with the four-member majority urging a speedy decision while members allied with Mayor David N. Dinkins warned against rushing the process.   With the board's self-imposed June 30 deadline approaching for the selection of a successor to Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, the debate erupted as the board met with the committee selected in March to oversee the search.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hevesi Urges Rivals to Limit Underwriters' Contributions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alan G. Hevesi, the Assemblyman from Queens who is running for City Comptroller, yesterday challenged his two rivals to voluntarily limit campaign contributions from firms that underwrite city bonds.    Seeking to take advantage of the widespread perception that firms use campaign contributions to influence the selection of bond underwriters, Mr. Hevesi, a senior member of the Assembly, also said he would introduce legislation that would force the city to put out to competitive bidding the bulk of its underwriting business.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: Socialist Jailed : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: KANSAS CITY - Mrs. Rose Pastor Stokes has been sentenced to ten years' imprisonment on each of three counts of disloyalty under the Espionage Act. Mrs. Stokes, a former editor at the "Jewish Daily News," New York, has been engaged in propaganda

nytimes_articles.headline: Mulroney Offering Troops to Help Blockade Haiti
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada told President Clinton today that his country was ready to send troops to enforce a blockade around Haiti, but Mr. Clinton committed himself to no more than a thorough review of United States options.   Administration officials said later that Washington was not prepared to move beyond far less aggressive measures to isolate the Haitian leadership, like freezing assets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Panthers Name Neilson Coach
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five months after being dismissed by the Rangers, Roger Neilson was today named head coach of the expansion Florida Panthers, the sixth team he will coach in the National Hockey League. Neilson, 58 years old, signed a three-year contract with a one-year option. No other terms were disclosed.   Under Neilson, who has a career won-lost-tied mark of 328-270-109, the Rangers were 19-17-4 last January and only 2 points out of second place in the Patrick Division when he was dismissed. Neilson noted today how in recent seasons Chicago and Pittsburgh had also been around the .500 mark at midseason and their coaches had remained as their teams went to the finals.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guadalajara Journal; Where Blast Leveled the Streets, Fear Still Loiters
nytimes_articles.abstract: They call it "that black day," and most people here can recall precisely where they were the moment more than a year ago when miles of underground sewer lines exploded, tearing this city open and leaving a deep scar of dirt and destruction that still has not healed.    "I had just come back from buying a few chickens for my son's birthday party," said Maria de Socorro Partida de Gomez, who has lived in Guadalajara for 40 years and who said that April 22, 1992, was seared into her memory.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Makes Kentucky's Bluegrass Blue
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Kentuckians Try to Reign in Suburbia" (news article, May 16), an otherwise excellent piece on urban encroachment in central Kentucky, has added misinformation to the blurred truth about common bluegrass, or poa pratensis, the luxuriant natural carpet that adorns half the lawns in suburban America.   Bluegrass is not named for its leaves, which are always green without a hint of azure, anil or topaz, whether they grow on limestone, granite, sandstone or igneous substrata. The grass is named for the seed heads, which appear during the spring and summer when allowed to grow unshorn and unmolested to a natural height of two to three feet.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; 'We Seemed A Little Bit Tight'
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S the oldest story in basketball: missed free throws.   Under those peach baskets nailed to the Y.M.C.A. gym in Springfield, Mass., a century ago, Dr. James Naismith, who invented the game, was probably the first to bemoan missed free throws. "Practice your free throws," coaches have preached ever since. "Practice your free throws."

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 991993 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Trying to show a tougher approach to enforcing environmental laws, the Clinton Administration last month levied an $11.1 million penalty against a company that falsely reported how much pollution it produced. It was the largest civil fine ever obtained under the Clean Air Act.   But in the days after Janet Reno, the Attorney General, and Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, jointly proclaimed what they said was a "loud and clear message" to polluters, some members of Congress, state officials and independent environmental experts have wondered just what sort of message was being sent.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. JOSEPH DUFFEY, former president of American University in Washington, who was also chancellor and president of the University of Massachusetts, is being sworn in this morning as the 13th director of the United States Information Agency. Then he will plunge immediately into the business at hand: explaining United States foreign policy by presiding over a panel discussion for U.S.I.A. employees, "A New Time: How Will America Present Itself to the World?"   The answer to that, Dr. Duffey said, will have to evolve with the times and the circumstances.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's like the stock market. The difference is you get your results immediately. And you can't get emotionally involved in securities. I mean, it is fun. Buy 100 shares of G.M. and there's no opening night party." -- ROGER BERLIND, a Broadway producer and investor.  [ C16:2. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Lawyer Is Missing. Now the Bad News.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pleading Guilty  By Scott Turow 386 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.    The intrigue swiftly introduced at the start of Scott Turow's latest legal thriller, "Pleading Guilty," seems sufficiently complex by itself to hold the reader's attention. Certainly it absorbs the members of the law firm of Gage & Griswell; the senior management of Trans-National Air, the firm's main client, and the financial-crimes division of the local police department in the nameless Midwestern American city where "Pleading Guilty" is set.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pop and Jazz in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Roy Haynes  Drummer Village Vanguard 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street Greenwich Village Through Sunday    Roy Haynes's show on Tuesday night was all about ornament. Jazz drumming changed radically during the be-bop era, moving from a time-keeping role, where the beats were made explicit, to a looser, more improvisatory and interactive role; Mr. Haynes, who was one of be-bop's best drummers, absorbed the revolution. His performance is an unending monologue, a stream of changing accents, ideas, suggestions and rhythmic angles.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jurors Decide for Psychoanalyst But Split on Award in Libel Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: The jurors in a $7.5 million libel suit brought by Jeffrey M. Masson against Janet Malcolm and The New Yorker magazine have decided in the plaintiff's favor but told the judge today that they were deadlocked on damages.    The jurors revealed their findings late on the third day of deliberations, in a message to Judge Eugene F. Lynch of Federal District Court here. They said they had reached unanimous decisions on all the questions except the amount of damages. Under the judge's instructions, they had to decide that Mr. Masson was libeled before moving on to consider damages. No Final Verdict    The jury's unusual message means there has been no final verdict in the closely watched case, which could still end in a mistrial, and the judge asked the panel of seven women and one man to return in the morning and continue their deliberations.

nytimes_articles.headline: State Comptroller McCall Honored at Hunter College
nytimes_articles.abstract: H. Carl McCall, the New York State comptroller and former president of the New York City Board of Education, delivered the keynote address yesterday at Hunter College's 167th commencement exercises.   The Hunter College president, Dr. Paul LeClerc, conferred the president's medal on Mr. McCall. Also receiving the President's medal was Frank Bonilla, a teacher, scholar and an advocate for Puerto Rican rights.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tobacco Ban in Minors
nytimes_articles.abstract: Major league baseball jumped on the anti-tobacco bandwagon yesterday -- with one foot. It announced that all minor league players, coaches and umpires would be forbidden to smoke or chew tobacco anywhere in their ball parks or on team buses.   The ban, which takes effect June 15, applies to more than 6,000 uniformed baseball personnel on the 160 minor league teams, but not to fans, employees of the clubs or to any major league players, including those sent down to the minors for rehabilitation. That's because major leaguers have rights under a collective bargaining agreement.

nytimes_articles.headline: AIDES SAY CLINTON WILL DROP NOMINEE FOR POST ON RIGHTS
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton has decided to withdraw the nomination of Lani Guinier to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, White House officials said today, an acknowledgement that her chances of winning confirmation have evaporated under an assault by critics of her proposals to bolster the political power of minorities.   The decision came at the end of a day in which Mr. Clinton publicly said he disagreed with some of her writings and offered only lukewarm support.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: TRACK AND FIELD  Milne Wins N.C.A.A. Discus Throw  Brian Milne, a sophomore from Penn State who had to give up track and field three years ago when he was diagnosed with Hodgkins' disease, won the discus throw last night on the opening day of the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships in New Orleans. Milne was in sixth place after four rounds, his throw of 191 feet 3 inches nearly 9 feet behind the leader, Ramon Jiminez-Gaona of the University of California. But on the fifth round, Milne's throw sailed 200-5 for the victory, the first in the event by an Easterner since Victor Frank of Yale won in 1949. The women's long jump was won by Daphnie Saunders, a Louisiana State junior from the Bahamas, who also won the N.C.A.A. indoor long jump less than three months ago. Her winning jump was 22 feet 2 1/2 inches. Shana Williams of Seton Hall, who also competed in the heptathlon, finished third in the long jump at 21-5 1/4. Earlier in the day, the hammer throw was won by Balazs Kiss, a 21-year-old Hungarian Olympian who now attends Southern California. His winning throw of 246-10 was the second longest in the meet's history. Pat McGrath of Manhattan College finished sixth (223-6). SOCCER  Norway Shocks England in Cup Qualifying  Norway put itself in position for its first World Cup berth since 1938, stunning England, 2-0, last night in Oslo. The match was played following a brawl that led the police to detain 73 English fans, who were accused of smashing up a bar. England hadn't lost to Norway since 1981. Oyvind Leonhardsen scored with three minutes left in the first half and Lars Bohinen ended a slick three-man attack by scoring three minutes after the break for Norway (5-0-1), which leads Group 2 with 11 points. England (3-1-3) is second with 9 points, followed by the Netherlands (3-1-2) and Poland (3-0-2) with 8 points each. The top two teams in each European group qualify for the World Cup finals next year in the United States. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: McGwire's Foot Placed in a Cast
nytimes_articles.abstract: MARK McGWIRE, bothered by persistent soreness from a bruise in his left heel, had the foot placed in a cast yesterday in hopes of speeding recovery. The Oakland Athletics slugger suffered the injury May 3 while sliding into third base during a game against the New York Yankees. He was placed on the disabled list two weeks later. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; On TV, Truth Is More Instant Than Fiction
nytimes_articles.abstract: Television movies based on fact are not just still with us, despite an escalation in warnings over the last couple of decades about blurred lines between fact and fiction; there are, in fact, more of them than ever. And the time lapse between factual event and television dramatization gets shorter and shorter. In recent weeks, NBC broadcast three "instant docudramas" within four days: "Ambush in Waco," "Hurricane Andrew: Triumph Over Disaster" and "Without Warning: Terror in the Towers." Not surprisingly, this particular achievement turned out to be dubious.    Most productions of this sort are doomed to mediocrity. Rushed into low-budget production, they are saddled with patched-together scripts and B-list actors obviously cruising at minimum-rehearsal speed. Worse, too many of the movies are forced into phony uplift modes, squeezing tearful sleaze out of genuine disasters, natural or man-made, whose survivors may still be distraught. That subtitle "Triumph Over Disaster" sums up prime-time television's determination to eliminate the negative, no matter what.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: The world's biggest bridge event, the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, will be played tomorrow night and Saturday afternoon, with 100,000 players in about 80 countries.   In the New York area, play will be at the following clubs:

nytimes_articles.headline: Senator Trails in Texas, and Slugs Alone
nytimes_articles.abstract: The bell is about to sound in the final round of the fight for a United States Senate seat from Texas, but this is no toe-to-toe slugfest.   It's more as if only one of the candidates -- the Democratic incumbent, Bob Krueger -- is storming around the ring. He is off to every corner of Texas, invoking all manner of serious accusations against his Republican challenger, State Treasurer Kay Bailey Hutchison.

nytimes_articles.headline: D'Amato Gets F.B.I. Protection Following Threats
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he has been under extra protection for the last month and skipped the annual Salute to Israel parade after the F.B.I. alerted the police to death threats against him.   A law-enforcement official who spoke on condition of anonymity later said that Mr. D'Amato was one of two lawmakers to be threatened by what is believed to be the same group of Islamic fundamentalists.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Yugoslavia, a Backlash Is Stinging Serbia's Leader
nytimes_articles.abstract: The politics of Yugoslavia sharpened today when the rule of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia was attacked as totalitarian by political opponents high and low.   At the same time, after a night of violent anti-Government demonstrations in which a police officer was killed and 32 people were injured, riot police maintained a conspicuous presence on the streets of the capital. With the country's foremost opposition leader still in custody after being beaten by police truncheons, the police were wary about more trouble. An Unusual Challenge    The level of public criticism directed at Mr. Milosevic was exceptional; his control of the instruments of power is usually unchallenged. For six months, as the country fell under punishing sanctions and pursued a foreign policy that alienated most of the world, his opponents lay low as he used his position of President of the Serbian republic to dominate Yugoslavia. Of the original six republics, Serbia and Montenegro are the last ones left in the Yugoslav federation.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Official Warns of Tensions More Threatening Than Bosnia's
nytimes_articles.abstract: The deputy head of United Nations forces in the Balkans said today that ethnic strife in the Kosovo region of southern Serbia and in Croatia were potentially more dangerous than the current fighting in Bosnia.   The official, Cedric Thornberry, the top civilian executive in charge of 25,210 United Nations personnel stationed throughout countries that used to be republics of Yugoslavia, said the conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina was "a confusing image of general mayhem with the danger of descent into anarchy in many areas."

nytimes_articles.headline: President Again Postpones Unveiling of a Health Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Preoccupied with efforts to win approval for his economic program, President Clinton has again postponed his proposal to remake the nation's medical system and has allowed his wife's task force on health care to expire.   As a result of the new delays by the Administration, Congress is highly unlikely to pass comprehensive health-care legislation this year. In a speech on Feb. 17, Mr. Clinton said Congress must pass such legislation "this year -- not next year, not five years from now, but this year."

nytimes_articles.headline: Cynicism Explained : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Clinton, Even as He Flails, Is Right About Cynicism" (Opinion, May 24): .I am less generous than E.J. Dionne Jr. is in defending President Bill Clinton's attack on what he sees as the problem of widespread cynicism. Many people vot

nytimes_articles.headline: Time Running Out for Whitman's Republican Rivals
nytimes_articles.abstract: With the Republican primary for Governor just six days away, both opponents of the Republican front-runner, Christine Todd Whitman, insisted today that their own soundings showed not only that they were in the race, but that they would win.   But the consensus among political professionals, poll takers and others following the campaign is that Mrs. Whitman has a lead that probably cannot be overcome by June 8, although the race is tightening.

nytimes_articles.headline: Empire Blue Cross Has to Begin Healing Itself
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "Rehabilitating Empire Blue Cross" (editorial May 24): I would like to point out that New York State's health insurance playing field was recently leveled. Last year the Legislature recognized the dire situation at Empire Blue Cross and passed community rating legislation that became effective April 1.    Now every health insurance company in New York State that sells individual and small group policies is required to set its premiums by geographic regions and not discriminate by basing rates on the health of the policyholder or small group. This change should help stabilize all health insurance premiums in this market. However, realistically it will be at least a year before we can accurately analyze its effect.

nytimes_articles.headline: PARENT & CHILD
nytimes_articles.abstract: DR. RUTH A. LAWRENCE still clearly remembers feeling exhausted and inadequate after the birth of her first child in 1951. "I was totally overwhelmed, even though I'd read all the books," said Dr. Lawrence, a professor of pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Rochester. All of her professional training and work as a physician had not prepared her for the intensity of her emotions and the physical drain on her body that came with caring for a newborn baby.   "I realized how much useless advice I'd given to new parents because I didn't know what it was really like," added Dr. Lawrence, who went on to have eight more children.

nytimes_articles.headline: Serbian Forces Said to Overrun Muslim Villages
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Sarajevo radio reported today that Serbian nationalists had overrun several Muslim villages in the Gorazde enclave in eastern Bosnia.    The radio reports said the Serbian tank and infantry assaults were coming from all directions, and they spoke of thousands of refugees fleeing their villages toward Gorazde town, which also came under heavy shelling today.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart on the Media Business page on May 24, with an article about a salary dispute at The Wall Street Journal and its parent, Dow Jones & Company, misstated the minimum salary for beginning reporters at Reuters. Reuters says it is $41,126.80.

nytimes_articles.headline: Calendar: A Festival Of Roses
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rose Revelry  New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx; (718) 817-8700.    The garden is celebrating its rose collection, which is in peak bloom. On Saturday and Sunday, and on June 12 and 13, events will include guided tours of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden, which contains more than 2,700 plants; a farmer's market with cut flowers and fresh fruit and vegetables; Victorian crafts, and activities for children. There will also be concerts on June 13. Rose events will be held from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-15  NO PRISON FOR WINNIE MANDELA  South Africa's highest appeals court upheld Winnie Mandela's conviction for the kidnapping of four black youths, but said she would not go to prison for her role in a crime that opened deep wounds in the anti-apartheid movement.  A1  GUATEMALAN IN EL SALVADOR  News analysis: When President Jorge Serrano Elias startled Guatemalans last week with the announcement that he was dissolving the Congress and suspending the Constitution, his seizure of power seemed to have been accomplished at a stroke. The military backed his actions. The President has now fled to El Salvador, this time after the army ousted him.  A3

nytimes_articles.headline: Speed and Intrigue Mark Final Workouts for Belmont
nytimes_articles.abstract: One and a half miles. Once around Belmont Park, the longest race track in North America. It is a distance farther than any 3-year-old horse has raced, and yet 14 or 15 of them will race that far on Saturday in the 125th running of the Belmont Stakes, the third and most demanding event in the Triple Crown series.   In the swirl of traffic on the main track early yesterday, a track crammed with famous horses booked into the Belmont or the half-dozen other stakes that will festoon this weekend's racing in New York, the chief topic was distance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Home Video
nytimes_articles.abstract: Movies on a 5-Inch CD    At the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago this week, the talk is of the 5-inch compact video disk called CD-ROM, which one day may hold movies the way CD's now hold music.   Virtually ignored is the movie disk already available, the 12-inch laser disk. With about one million players in use and more than 8,000 titles available, the format occupies a niche among movie buffs who appreciate its quality of picture and sound.

nytimes_articles.headline: Schools Can't Segregate Handicapped Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As the parent of a handicapped child, I was gratified by "When Disabled Students Enter Regular Classrooms" (front page, May 19). However, you omit a problem I have seen time and again in my local schools.    There still are quite a number of school principals who shun the presence of multiply handicapped children in their schools, a prejudice not easily set aside. The children, though allowed into the school to satisfy the law's requirements, are treated as though they were living before the civil rights era: they are banished to a classroom that is isolated from the main part of the school and their peers. Their classroom is usually the smallest, most cramped quarter in the building, more often than not a converted lounge without windows and without sufficient space to maneuver wheelchairs and walkers.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Rough World of American Politics, Asian-Americans Stand Out, as Rare
nytimes_articles.abstract: If he wins election next week as mayor of Los Angeles, Michael Woo, a third-generation Chinese-American, will become the first Asian-American mayor of a major American city. But to get this far in politics, he has had to leave his Asian roots far behind.   Like most of the few other Asian-Americans who hold elective office in the United States, Mr. Woo has been required by politics to go against his own inclinations, to wade into controversies, to seek headlines, to lobby aggressively for campaign money.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ballet Theater Revives, With Help From Friends
nytimes_articles.abstract: American Ballet Theater, which last September was close to financial collapse, announced yesterday that it had paid a $2 million bank debt and raised an additional $1 million toward a new production of "The Nutcracker" to be performed in California in early December. The company also announced the formation of "The Partnership for A.B.T.," a special fund-raising task force headed by Peter Joseph, the new president of Ballet Theater's board, and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Peter Duchin and Wilbur Ross, a senior partner at Rothschild Inc., who played a major role in saving the New-York Historical Society.    "It's not a question of survival any more," Mr. Joseph, chairman and chief executive officer of Rosecliff, a merchant banking company, said yesterday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Washington at Work; Untested Role for Moynihan in Budget Fight
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has played many roles in many areas of public life, ranging happily from foreign to domestic policy, from ethnic conflict on the international scene to the problems of children and poverty at home.   But the New York Democrat is still a novice as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, a job he began six months ago, and he faces the challenge of a chairman's lifetime. President Clinton's economic plan has lurched through the House -- just barely -- and landed with a somewhat ominous thud in Mr. Moynihan's lap.

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   AL -- Upheld the three-game suspension of Cleveland Indians outfielder Albert Belle and announced it will begin Friday.   BOSTON RED SOX -- Activated Mike Greenwell, outfielder, from the 15-day disabled list. Optioned Jim Byrd, infielder, to Pawtucket of the International League. National League

nytimes_articles.headline: Gun Licensees Scrutinized
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Police Department and the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms intend to visit 993 gun collectors and dealers who hold Federal firearms licenses to make sure they are not using them to buy or ship guns across state lines, the two agencies announced yesterday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; Sad State of State
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bill Clinton has made two major forays into foreign affairs so far. His first was a winner: the embrace of Boris Yeltsin at the Vancouver summit probably helped democratic reformers increase the size of their victory in the Russian referendum.    His second was a loser: he announced his intention to coerce the Bosnian Serbs to the peace table with air power, then dispatched his Secretary of State to Europe to bring the allies along; instead, Warren Christopher brought back the first public humiliation of an American President since World War II.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption yesterday about camels that were being led through Cairo to a slaughterhouse referred incorrectly in some editions to the Muslim holy day of Id al-Adha. It is the Feast of the Sacrifice, marking the sparing of the life of Abraham's son Isaac. The end of the penitential month of Ramadan, Id al-Fitr, was celebrated in March.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sihanouk Seeking Settlement By Government and Royalists
nytimes_articles.abstract: As election returns showed the Government apparently headed for a defeat, Prince Norodom Sihanouk tried to broker a settlement between the Government and the royalist opposition party that would prevent the Government from using force to hold onto power, United Nations officials said today.    So far, the two sides have not agreed to meet.

nytimes_articles.headline: Finals to Start Wednesday
nytimes_articles.abstract: The National Basketball Association championship series will begin Wednesday night, June 9. Starting with the opener, games will be played on Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays until the four-of-seven-game series concludes. Wednesday and Friday games will start at 9 P.M., Eastern time, and Sunday games will begin at 7 P.M. All games will be televised nationally by NBC.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. and North Koreans Discuss Nuclear Dispute
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States began a last-ditch effort yesterday to persuade North Korea to ease a dispute over nuclear weapons by reversing its decision to withdraw from the treaty to halt their spread.    But a United States diplomat said his delegation had not made "any significant progress" during seven hours of talks in New York with its North Korean counterpart. Another meeting is scheduled for tomorrow.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bulls Defeat Knicks In a Tense Game 5
nytimes_articles.abstract: Defying the home court advantage, the Chicago Bulls beat the Knicks, 97-94, at Madison Square Garden last night to take a 3-2 lead in their four-of-seven game National Basketball Association playoff series.    Unless the Knicks can return the insult at Chicago Stadium tomorrow night, the Bulls will clinch the series and set their sights on a third straight championship.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemala: Democracy Recouped?
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a rule, military coups do not produce wholly positive results, and the Guatemalan Army's ouster of President Jorge Serrano on Tuesday is unlikely to prove the exception. Yet for Guatemala, and its army, the removal of a would-be civilian dictator is a big step forward from the brutal military interventions of the recent past.    Outside pressure -- especially the Clinton Administration's threat to suspend lucrative trade and investment incentives -- helped undermine Mr. Serrano's ambitions. But it was the widespread hostility of Guatemalan civil society that assured his early downfall.

nytimes_articles.headline: Italian Blast: 'Dark Force'?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The bomb that blew through the Uffizi Gallery last week has again forced Italians to acknowledge a central paradox of their artistic heritage, that its very size and wealth and ubiquity make it impossible to protect.   But they have also begun to revise their perception of Italy, from a place on the verge of change to a place where change is impossible because "occult forces" behind the public face of political power always conspire to make it so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trade Bait? Bonilla's Bat Sizzles
nytimes_articles.abstract: The home run crashed into the bleachers in left at Wrigley Field. Bobby Bonilla crossed the plate. The right fielder's statistics were pumped fuller, and his week of offensive terror made that much more imposing.   The two-run, fourth-inning home run, which made the afternoon's 11-3 demolition of the Cubs certain, if not complete, also had the effect of starting once more the debate about Bonilla's future with the Mets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kurds and Christians Live in Harmony
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Christian Sects in Kurdish Lands Dwindle" (letter, May 24), Alastair Bruton claims that the numbers of Christians living in the Kurdish area in the north of Iraq and southeast of Turkey have been reduced from 25,000 to 200 or 300 "because the Kurds told them they had no future in a land the Kurds would soon control." Mr. Bruton concludes by appealing for the linkage of "safeguards" to Western aid earmarked for the peoples of Kurdistan-Iraq because otherwise the West will be facilitating "ethnic cleansing" there.   Throughout this century, Muslim Kurds and Christian Assyrians and Chaldeans in Kurdistan-Iraq have enjoyed good and cooperative relations. In the 1930's, for example, the Kurds did not retaliate against Christians who displaced them, in collaboration with British colonialists, from the oil-rich area of Kirkuk. More recently, some Christians have joined Kurdish political parties.   In the 1980's, many Christians left the Kurdish area for Baghdad or destinations abroad for economic reasons. Iraqi Kurds, themselves victims of chemical warfare and an operation that, it is estimated, claimed the lives of 180,000 Kurds, were hardly in a position to force any other people out of the region.    Some Christians fled to Turkey in the April 1991 refugee exodus and refused to return for economic reasons or because they had no homes to which to return. This is documented in reports released by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and in an April 1992 investigation report by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.   In the last year, in preparation for the May 1992 election, the Kurdistan Front set aside 5 seats (out of 105) for Christians in the new Kurdish Parliament. This quota assured the representation of Chaldeans and other Christian groups. Because the two major parties hold 50 seats each, the Christian members of the Kurdish Parliament will cast the deciding votes should a stalemate arise.   As the Iraqi military again looms as an ominous presence on the horizon of Kurdistan-Iraq, the fledgling democracy deserves and needs Western humanitarian aid as long as its leaders apply the law equitably to all people. SALAH AZIZ  President, Badlisy Center for Kurdish Studies Tallahassee, Fla., May 25, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Impasse Over Damages in New Yorker Libel Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: The celebrated libel trial pitting Jeffrey M. Masson against Janet Malcolm ended inconclusively today when a Federal jury deadlocked on monetary damages after deciding that the writer had defamed him with five fabricated quotations in her article about him in The New Yorker.    A new trial is now likely in the tortuous, decadelong case between a prim East Coast writer and a flamboyant West Coast analyst. But it remains to be decided by Judge Eugene F. Lynch of the United States District Court here whether the entire case will be heard again or merely the damage portion, and whether The New Yorker will remain a defendant.

nytimes_articles.headline: Exiled Haitian Leader Addresses L.I.U.-Brooklyn
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the exiled President of Haiti, delivered the main address via videotape at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University for its 63d commencement, which was held yesterday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.   Father Aristide, who was deposed in a September 1991 coup, spoke to the 1,000 graduates about the movement to restore democracy in Haiti.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sea Cliffs  Aquarium for Wildlife Conservation West Eighth Street  and Surf Avenue Coney Island, Brooklyn (718) 265-3474 Recommended for all ages    Out in Coney Island, where the fish still hang out in schools and the Cyclone roller coaster has been carrying riders since 1927, there is a new marine mammal habitat, Sea Cliffs, at what used to be called the New York Aquarium.

nytimes_articles.headline: Park Ave. Car Ban May Clean Air, but Not Words
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City officials closed a busy section of Park Avenue to traffic for two hours yesterday, and this is what happened:   Electric-powered cars were displayed, volunteers with pedicabs offered free rides and assorted politicians showed up to voice support for anything that would cut pollution and to urge car owners to change their wicked ways.

nytimes_articles.headline: Three's Company: Guinier, Reagan, Bush
nytimes_articles.abstract: The shrill attacks on Lani Guinier, President Clinton's nominee to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, give to those who know her a sense of Kafkaesque unreality.   Her experience, character, respect for the law and balanced approach to the issues would make her one of the finest assistant attorneys general ever to serve our country. She is superbly qualified, mainstream and pro-integrationist in the tradition of Thurgood Marshall. It is essential, if democratic principles are to be preserved, that President Clinton give her the opportunity to defend her record before the Senate Judiciary Committee. For him to yank the nomination now would not only be unfair but, some would say, political cowardice.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jerusalem Journal; Strike! Strike! Strike! Some Arabs Feel Cudgeled
nytimes_articles.abstract: Commercial strikes? In the Muslim Quarter of the Old City, a shoe-store owner repeated key words of the question put to him, then raised a hand to forehead level to make his point about having had it up to there.   "I'm tired of the whole thing -- the strikes and the intifada," he said, using the Arabic word for the Palestinian uprising against Israel.

nytimes_articles.headline: SOUTH AFRICA FOES SET DATE FOR VOTE OPEN TO ALL RACES
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Government and most of South Africa's opposition parties settled tonight on a date -- April 27, 1994 -- for elections in which the country's black majority will cast their first votes.    The tentative agreement, coming after a year and a half of fitful negotiations, would set a timetable for ending more than three centuries of white rule.

nytimes_articles.headline: Air Miles:The Customers Amex Forgot
nytimes_articles.abstract: The American Express company has left tens of thousands of its international dollar-paying customers in limbo, by excluding them from its Membership Miles frequent flier program as it begins to extend the plan around the world. .Although these customer

nytimes_articles.headline: Revenge on Two Whistle-Blowers
nytimes_articles.abstract: No top official loves a whistle-blower. Consider two scientists at the National Institutes of Health, Walter Stewart and Ned Feder, who have waged a lonely battle to expose fraud and misconduct in scientific research. They have written papers on scientific misconduct, investigated plagiarism and served as a conduit for other scientists charging misconduct. Along the way they have angered many in the scientific establishment who deemed them obsessed, arrogant and too willing to tarnish reputations on flimsy evidence.   Now the two crusaders appear to have gone too far, giving their enemies an excuse to muzzle them. Their sin: using a cluster of software programs they developed (dubbed a "plagiarism machine") to look for examples of copying in a biography of Abraham Lincoln. It was always murky how much leeway the self-appointed crusaders, hired as research scientists, should have to pursue investigations. But it seems indisputable that the field of history is remote from their responsibilities.

nytimes_articles.headline: Oilers to Marshall: No Deal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Houston called off a trade for Washington Redskins linebacker WILBER MARSHALL after the Oilers apparently agreed to a contract with the Pro Bowler.   "We've decided that we don't want to pursue the trade because we don't want to give the Redskins a first- and fifth-round draft choice for him," said an Oilers spokesman, CHIP NAMIAS.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gunman Kills A Detective In Courthouse
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eluding elaborate security measures, a gunman apparently bent on vengeance made his way to the 11th floor of the Essex County Court Building here today and fatally shot a Newark police detective in the back of the head.    The detective, John Sczyrek, 30, of Belleville, had been returning to the courtroom to testify as a key witness in the drug trial of a relative of the gunman, officials said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; "A Confusion Happened"
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Dickens's Department of Circumlocution has found a new recruit in Mahfouz al-Ansari, an Egyptian editor. When his semiofficial newspaper erred by quoting President Hosni Mubarak too accurately, the editor published this elegantly fuzzy correction:    "A confusion happened and a mistake was made. I attributed these comments to the President, but in fact they came in the analysis, explanation and information which the editors put before the President, quoting American newspapers and media."

nytimes_articles.headline: Graf and Fernandez Waste No Time in Gaining Final
nytimes_articles.abstract: The two women's semifinals at the French Open this afternoon turned out to be brief affairs but momentous occasions.   Top-seeded Steffi Graf not only pulverized her German understudy, Anke Huber, 6-1, 6-1, to reach her sixth final at Roland Garros, she also regained the No. 1 ranking she lost to Monica Seles just over two years ago. Graf had reigned supreme on the women's circuit for a record 186 weeks. Then Seles, who is currently recovering from a stab wound inflicted on April 30 by a deranged fan of Graf's, usurped the top ranking in March 1991 and held it with a pit bull's tenacity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Manufacturing Job Losses Cripple the Economy
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "New Jersey Slump: Go-Go Suburbs Went" (front page, May 20) deals extensively with the symptoms, but relegates the cause to one startling statistic buried deep in the article -- that New Jersey "has lost 200,000 jobs since 1989, and 130,000 of the losses were in manufacturing."

nytimes_articles.headline: Sonics Breeze To Force Game 7
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley shot his mouth, but not the basketball tonight. He groused at referees, aimed his index finger at them as if it were a gun, slammed a ball halfway to the rafters, incited fans and made no redeeming contribution to the Phoenix Suns. Maybe he was saving his aching body for a deciding seventh game in this Western Conference final, which is exactly what he has on his hands.   Seattle was the more stolid team tonight, and the Sonics delivered an emphatic 118-102 victory before 14,812 at the Seattle Center Coliseum. The series, tame for the first five games, finally has some passion and it will be settled Saturday afternoon in Phoenix.

nytimes_articles.headline: Next Title Defense for Bowe?
nytimes_articles.abstract: ROCK NEWMAN, manager of heavyweight champion RIDDICK BOWE, asked the International Boxing Federation to make Bowe's first mandatory defense against either MICHAEL MOORER or OLIVER McCALL. Moorer is listed second in the latest I.B.F. rankings and McCall is rated third. But first, Newman said, he expected Bowe and former champion EVANDER HOLYFIELD to agree to a rematch in the near future.(AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Love Swings Straight Back Into 1992
nytimes_articles.abstract: A few short months ago it seemed the surest thing in golf was that 1993 would belong to Davis Love 3d.   He was coming off a PGA Tour season in which he won three official tournaments and more than $1 million, and he had added three more unofficial victories in the last two months of the year. To top it off, Love won this year's opening event, the Tournament of Champions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Coach Names Squad for U.S. Cup '93
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bora Milutinovic, head coach of the United States national soccer team, named eight European-based players yesterday to his 22-man roster for the United States Cup '93 tournament, which begins Sunday in New Haven.   Four of the eight players -- Thomas Dooley, Tab Ramos, Frank Klopas and Eric Wynalda -- will miss the opener at the Yale Bowl against Brazil because of previous commitments. They will join the team in time for matches against Germany and England.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemala Army Names Vice President as Leader
nytimes_articles.abstract: Amid signs that the military has again taken control of Guatemala's chaotic political situation, the Government announced today that the Vice President, who was supposed to have resigned when President Jorge Serrano Elias was overthrown, was taking over as the country's new leader.   The Vice President, Gustavo Espina Salguero, had still not been sworn in as President tonight, and it is not clear that he has the necessary political support to be ratified by Congress.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: BETTY FRIEDAN has been hospitalized at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center since Tuesday, suffering from an infection that causes severe back pain.   Ms. Friedan underwent surgery twice last month at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan in Los Angeles, to replace an aorta valve. One replacement came from a pig, the second from a human.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Told of Cease-Fire in Muslim Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: The commander of the United Nations military forces in Bosnia said today that the leader of the Bosnian Serbs had told him that he had ordered a cease-fire around the besieged Muslim town of Gorazde.   Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon has been pressing Bosnian Serbs for days to allow military observers into Gorazde, which has been designated a safe area by the United Nations. "I have insisted that these observers must be deployed no later than tomorrow to show good faith," the general said after his meeting with Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader.

nytimes_articles.headline: Edberg Derailed by Medvedev
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stefan Edberg referred to himself as being on the right track here at the French Open, where all he needed was the title in order to become the first man to collect all four Grand Slam crowns since Rod Laver mastered that elusive quad in 1969.   But in Andrei Medvedev, an upstart teen-ager from Ukraine, Edberg today ran smack into a runaway train in their rain-delayed quarterfinal on the stadium court. In the best tradition of the local fountainry, Edberg's hairline was spouting rivulets of water from the effort of trying to counteract the grim power of Medvedev. And the youngster's seemingly automated service returns pressured the Swede to be perfect. Which he wasn't.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gay Film Festival: The Personal and the Political
nytimes_articles.abstract: In "I'll Love You Forever . . . Tonight," Edgar Michael Bravo's gritty portrait of gay life in Los Angeles, a sullen young photographer is coaxed by his sometime lover into spending the weekend with some friends at a Palm Springs hideaway. What is supposed to be a restful little vacation turns into a joyless round of hard drinking and cold-blooded sexual games played by five good-looking men who seem totally at loose ends. Their emotional cruelty reminds the photographer of his childhood abuse by his father, whom he eventually telephones for an excruciating confrontation.    The tone of Mr. Bravo's film, which is being shown today and tomorrow at the Cinema Village as part of the New Festival, also called the 1993 New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival, suggests Mart Crowley's play "The Boys in the Band," as it might be adapted and updated for 1993 in the spirit of Bret Easton Ellis's novel "Less Than Zero." If the film offers a bleak picture of one segment of gay life, it carries a nasty ring of truth.

nytimes_articles.headline: Good Life in Gabon Comes at a Heavy Price
nytimes_articles.abstract: Against a backdrop of opulent residences and elegant restaurants, Boulevard Georges Pompidou, a scenic roadway overlooking the Atlantic coast here, could easily be mistaken for a glittering stretch along the French Riviera.    It is all part of the good life that this tiny Central African country of sandy beaches, isolated coves and ruggedly beautiful mountains can offer. It is a splendor, however, that costs dearly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Majority in Poll Back Ban on Handguns
nytimes_articles.abstract: Americans watching the increase in gunshot injuries and deaths among the country's children are beginning to see gun control as a question of public health rather than just a matter of crime prevention, according to a new survey made public today.   The survey, by Louis Harris of LH Research Inc., showed that one adult in five knows a child who had been shot by another child, and another 12 percent know a child who shot himself by accident. The study, done under a grant from the Chicago-based Joyce Foundation for the Harvard School of Public Health, found that three-quarters of adults surveyed believed "young people's safety is endangered by there being so many guns around these days."  9 Out of 10 Back Bill    As a result, the new poll found, public opinion is rapidly swinging in favor of more stringent gun control measures.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Games Meticulous And Mean
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The Music of Chance" was shown as part of the recent New Directors/ New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 19, 1993. The film opens today at the Fine Arts, 4 West 58th Street, Manhattan.    A miniature city is the haunting centerpiece of "The Music of Chance," Philip Haas's cool, methodical film version of Paul Auster's equally meticulous 1990 novel. Called City of the World, it is the bizarre play thing of Willie Stone (Joel Grey), a former optometrist who made his fortune by winning the lottery. Together with his friend Bill Flower (Charles Durning), Stone lives in an isolated mansion and contemplates the meaning of fate while playing childlike games. The City of the World is his masterwork. James Nashe (Mandy Patinkin) and Jack Pozzi (James Spader) are his victims.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Garbo's Grittier 'Anna Christie'
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN Garbo talked in the 1930 Hollywood version of "Anna Christie," she had to speak not only English but also the language of Eugene O'Neill. Fighting her way through the "Py gollys" and "Now, me old buckos" of the 1922 play (which gives Anna a Swedish father and an Irish suitor), Garbo struggled visibly to match the expansiveness of the material. She gave a stirring but stagy performance under the direction of Clarence Brown, who had guided her through the 1927 "Flesh and the Devil," would later direct her in "Anna Karenina" (1935) and clearly understood the Garbo mystique. At the same time, in another language, Garbo did something unusual with "Anna Christie": she made it again.   "Her contralto voice seems better suited to talking German than English," wrote the New York Times critic Mordaunt Hall when the German "Anna Christie," directed by Jacques Feyder on the same sets that Mr. Brown had used, opened here briefly in 1931. "Her presence is if anything more striking in this current work than in the English version."

nytimes_articles.headline: Babbitt a Candidate for High Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton said today that "we're close" to announcing a choice for a Supreme Court seat, and White House officials said the short list for that nomination now included Bruce Babbitt, the Interior Secretary.   Presidential aides said that although Mr. Clinton might yet select a sitting judge to replace Justice Byron R. White, who will retire this month, he wanted a candidate with whom he is close and comfortable, as he is with Mr. Babbitt.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tyson and Cayton Settle
nytimes_articles.abstract: After four years, MIKE TYSON and his former boxing manager, BILL CAYTON, decided to settle their legal suits against each other, according to court papers reviewed Wednesday in United States District Court in Manhattan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pay Too High?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "At What Point Is Pay Too High?" asks the headline over your article on the compensation of Leonard Tow, chief executive officer of Citizens Utilities (Business Day, May 21).    I suggest an appropriate answer to that question is one my manager at a major corporation gave me years ago. "Your salary," he told me, "is designed to keep you sullen but not mutinous. If you're satisfied, it's too high. If you quit, it's too low. The right amount is somewhere between these two limits." SHERMAN SIEGEL  King of Prussia, Pa., May 21, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Animal Laboratory Evacuated After Power Loss
nytimes_articles.abstract: Scientists were evacuated from a building at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center on Wednesday morning after a brief power failure triggered a release of toxic formaldehyde gas.   Today, officials of the Long Island Lighting Company said that the power failure was caused by an osprey nest atop a transmission line pole.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sotheby's Challenged In Selling Declaration
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is a first printing of the Declaration of Independence -- a clear, crisp copy that sold for $2.4 million two years ago -- and yesterday it became enmeshed in a Manhattan court fight over ownership and resale rights.   A fine arts investment firm, Visual Equities Inc., of Atlanta, obtained a court order temporarily blocking Sotheby's from selling the Declaration after charging that the Manhattan auction house had misled the firm and tried to defraud it at an unsuccessful auction last month.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Min; Our Friend Qaddafi
nytimes_articles.abstract: For a while, many Americans asked themselves a sensible and healthy question every time they walked aboard a passenger plane -- is this another Pan Am 103?   The question was sensible because terrorists can do again what they did on Dec. 21, 1988 -- bring down a planeload of 259 people. And it was healthy, because as long as Americans asked it, there was a chance that terrorism could be stopped permanently.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: PRISONER'S DEATH RULED A HOMICIDE   An epileptic prisoner who died in police custody at a Manhattan hospital was beaten to death while he was lying face down with his wrists manacled behind him and unable to breathe adequately, the New York City Medical Examiner said. He ruled the death a homicide. A1. TEEN-AGE JOBLESSNESS AT 40 PERCENT   Unemployment among New York City's teen-agers rose to 40 percent in the first three months this year, the city says. That is nearly double the rate of two years ago and the worst in the 25 years that records have been kept. A1. NEW YORK CITY  PRIEST PLANS HUNGER STRIKE   A suspended Episcopal priest says that he intends to go on a hunger strike at the diocese office until Bishop Richard F. Grein meets with him to discuss the suspension. His supporters also vowed to continue their protests until he is reinstated to his Mott Haven church. B2. ONE-MONTH SENTENCE IN DEATH   A man has been sentenced to barely a month's time in jail, to be served on weekends, for his role in the death of an artist in a Greenwich Village street fight in 1991. The sentence drew angry responses from the victim's friends, who have assailed the handling of the case. B2. DIRE FINANCIAL PICTURE UNVEILED   All but giving up hope that the city would receive much of the state and Federal aid they had been seeking, senior aides to Mayor Dinkins have presented their most dire view yet of the city's fiscal condition. B3. DAILY NEWS PICKS JERSEY CITY SITE   New Jersey state officials and top officials of The Daily News said the newspaper would put a new printing plant in Jersey City. The planned move to an unused Clorox plant ends a heated battle between New York and New Jersey, which have both been seeking to win the plant's 1,600 jobs. B3. A 1776 copy of the Declaration of Independence is the subject of a suit. B3. New York City officials closed a busy section of Park Avenue to traffic for two hours. B3. The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide delivered the main address via videotape at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University for its 63d commencement. B4.  REGION  CAMPAIGNING FOR GOVERNOR   Jim Wallwork came to Morristown to greet shoppers and noshers around the Morristown Green at a campaign stop that showed the difficulties of winning votes in the Republican primary for New Jersey governor. B5. LONG ISLAND COMPANIES SEEK HELP   With economists predicting continued decline for Long Island's military industry, a group representing more than 100 Defense Department subcontractors implored Federal and state officials to help them. B5. Gov. Florio signed bills toughening penalties in car thefts. B5. A power failure at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center forced an evacuation. B5. Chronicle B4  Our Towns by James Barron B5

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton's Reversals; As President Drops Justice Nominee, Many Wonder What He Stands For
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton is talking once again about giving the middle class a tax cut, although no time too soon. As he urgently hunts for the middle ground, or at least the stable ground, he has turned to the man who once helped package what Democrats like to call the Decade of Greed. And he spent the better part of the week dancing between his party's left and right flanks before ditching an old Yale Law School friend as his choice to enforce the nation's civil rights laws.   "This has nothing to do with the political center," Mr. Clinton said tonight at the White House in announcing his decision to drop the nomination of Lani Guinier to be the new civil rights chief in the Justice Department. "This is about my center."

nytimes_articles.headline: Daily News to Shift Printing to Jersey City
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Jersey state officials and the owner of The Daily News said yesterday that the newspaper would replace plants in Brooklyn and Kearny, N.J., with one in Jersey City.   The planned move, to a Clorox plant, ends a heated battle between New York and New Jersey for the plant's 1,600 jobs. The decision is a victory for New Jersey and its Governor, Jim Florio, in an election year in which jobs are an important issue.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Abandons His Nominee For Rights Post Amid Opposition
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton tonight withdrew his nomination of Lani Guinier to be the new civil rights chief in the Justice Department, saying that after belatedly reading her legal writings he decided he could not defend many of her views on bolstering the political power of blacks.   Mr. Clinton, who met with Ms. Guinier for nearly two hours at the White House before the announcement, conceded that he would not have nominated Ms. Guinier if he had read her academic papers before he sent her name to the Senate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kerri Scharlin, Darren M. Brown  Dooley Le Cappellaine 252 Lafayette Street SoHo Through tomorrow    These two solo shows stress the continuing interest in context, in the world around and beyond the art object. The work in Kerri Scharlin's show has been made by art students, who drew and sculptured from a nude model who was the artist herself. Their treatments of her face and body attest to different degrees of talent and style. (The small clay sculptures are sometimes rather good.) But the main point here seems to be that it is the female model who occupies center stage. A new kind of one-woman show.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins Plans More Cuts To Fill $280 Million Gap
nytimes_articles.abstract: All but giving up hope that New York City would receive much of the state and Federal aid they had been seeking, senior aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday presented their most dire view yet of the city's fiscal condition.   They said they would now be forced to cut city spending by $280 million in the next fiscal year, including scaling back by half the 8,000 workers they had planned to hire. The spending plan that Mr. Dinkins presented last month called for a net increase of 1,500 workers during the next year; officials now expect to shrink the work force.

nytimes_articles.headline: Optimistic About Poland : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "In Poland, Reform Has Meant Pain and Division" (Opinion, May 5) by Konstanty Gebert: .I work in Poland for a U.S. group that channels voluntary assistance from the United States to Eastern Europe. .Mr. Gebert apparently finds the

nytimes_articles.headline: Diner's Journal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Daniel in the Mainstream    Is the new Manhattan restaurant Daniel merely Le Cirque without Sirio? Well, no and yes. When Daniel Boulud left his mentor, Sirio Maccioni, owner of Le Cirque, last year to open his own place, fans of his astonishingly diversified French cooking wondered where his talents would lead next. Would he paddle down some exotic tributary the way Jean-Georges Vongerichten of Jo-Jo did when he opened Vong? Would he embrace some neglected regional French cuisine?   As a recent visit to Daniel reveals, Mr. Boulud did no such thing. Daniel, on East 76th Street near Fifth Avenue, offers the kind of technically impeccable, labor-intensive French cooking that made Mr. Boulud a star at Le Cirque. People looking for innovation may be disappointed; those looking for world-class French fare will not be.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Echoes of the Vietnam War Are Still Resounding
nytimes_articles.abstract: The late, great Vietnam War lasted more than 10 years -- longer than the United States engagement in two World Wars and the Korean War -- and it continues to be a guiding fact in American foreign and military policy. The Vietnam Syndrome remains a cautionary warning against adventurism in no-win wars or, contrariwise, as a lingering attitude that some unrepentant hawks want discarded. The famous hundred-hour victory in the Persian Gulf was sui generis; it hasn't changed the views of key American decision makers, who do not want to stumble into the current ethnic-religious-border war in the Balkans.   Nearly two decades after the end of the Vietnam War, a new round of books explores the war's aims; how and why the United States got involved; who the Vietnamese people are and what they thought about the foreigners who came to their villages as warriors; the behavior of American soldiers in battle; the campus wars and the peace movement at home, and how correspondents reported the war while facing pressure from their publications, networks and government.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Reaching Out for Love -- and Money
nytimes_articles.abstract: What do these numbers say about America?   A.T.&T. handled roughly 120 million long-distance calls on an average weekday in 1989. On Oct. 18, the day after the San Francisco earthquake, that number leaped to 145 million. (America has a loving heart.)

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943:A Yangtze Grave : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: CHUNGKING - [From our New York edition:] Aided by air power on a large scale for the first time in the war, Chinese forces have broken the back of the Japanese offensive in central China and tonight are standing on the west bank of the Yangtze River oppos

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: TRACK AND FIELD  L.S.U. Women Near 7th Straight Title  Danyel Mitchell won the women's discus throw yesterday as Louisiana State's women's team rolled toward its seventh consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association championship at Tad Gormley Stadium in New Orleans. Mitchell's winning throw was 186 feet 6 inches, 40 inches better than the 183-2 of runner-up Dawn Dumble of U.C.L.A. Third was Stacy Schroeder, a University of Florida freshman from Grand Island, N.Y. Schroeder, last year's New York state high school champion in the shot-put and discus, registered the best performance of her career with a throw of 180-1. Kelly Blair of Oregon, with 6,038 points, won the heptathlon. Fourth in the seven-event competition was Shana Williams of Seton Hall (5,640). Randy Jenkins of Tennessee won the men's high jump. Jenkins, who finished second in in 1991 but missed last year's meet because of Hodgkins' disease, won with a jump of 7 feet 5 3/4 inches.  Powell Long Jumps 27-10 3/4 for Victory  Mike Powell of the United States, the world-record holder at 29 feet 4 1/2 inches, got off his best long jump of the early outdoor season, leaping 27-10 3/4 to win the event at the Madrid International in Spain. Ivan Pedroso of Cuba, the 1993 world indoor champion, was second at 27-7 1/4. In the day's major upset, China's Li Tong defeated the Olympic silver medalist Tony Dees of the United States in the 110-meter hurdles in 13.62 seconds. Dees ran 13.70. Renaldo Nehemiah, the former world-record holder from the United States, was fifth in 13.82. (AP) COLLEGE BASEBALL  Cal Poly Eliminates Adelphi From Tourney  Grant Munger hit a pair of home runs to lead Cal Poly to an 11-5 victory over Adelphi in Montgomery, Ala., yesterday that propelled the Mustangs (39-18) into tomorrow night's championship game and eliminated the Panthers (32-17) from the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II tournament. Dom Gatti, the Division II player of the year, led the losers from Garden City, L.I., with three singles. (AP) ROWING  Brown and Penn Win Heats in Eights  Eighty-five crews from 23 colleges competed on the opening day of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's 91st regatta, at the Cooper River in Cherry Hill, N.J. The Brown varsity eight, which last month won the first part of rowing's triple crown, the Eastern Sprints, breezed through its qualifying heat yesterday, winning in 5 minutes 37.6 seconds. The other varsity heat winner, as expected, was Penn in 5:38.4. The 10 non-winners will row today in two repechage races, with first and second-place finishers qualifying for tomorrow's six-boat finale. Brown and Northeastern crews won the second varsity heats while freshman eights from Brown, Navy and Princeton placed first in their three heats.
